issue.title: Change pytest deprecation warnings into errors for 6.0 release

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

body:
I'll be reverting these entries from the CHANGELOG:

```
- `#6981 <https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/6981>`_: Deprecate the ``pytest.collect`` module as it's just aliases into ``pytest``.


- `#7097 <https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/7097>`_: The ``pytest._fillfuncargs`` function is now deprecated. This function was kept
  for backward compatibility with an older plugin.

  It's functionality is not meant to be used directly, but if you must replace
  it, use `function._request._fillfixtures()` instead, though note this is not
  a public API and may break in the future.
```

EDIT: done in https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/pull/7482

issue.title: Small fixes/updates to the 6.0.0rc1 CHANGELOG

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
- Grammar fixes
- Moved a few sections from Features to Improvements
- Used internal doc links when appropriate

body: For implementation towncrier support in setuptools_scm is intended and planned

> For implementation towncrier support in setuptools_scm is intended and planned

Not sure what you mean, can you elaborate please?
I strongly oppose combining declaration and triggering of warnings
@nicoddemus if the next guessed version is based on semver + towncrier inference, it's 7.0.dev... As soon as a breaking change is merged

Ahh I found it: https://github.com/pypa/setuptools_scm/issues/332

OK then, let's hold then.

> This will simplify our side because we won't need to change PytestDeprecationWarnings into errors anymore before each major release.

Is this a major headache? Making things conditional on our own `__version__` might cause some headaches of its own...

---


BTW, [Django does](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/internals/contributing/writing-code/submitting-patches/#deprecating-a-feature) something I like, which is embed the removal version in the warning type. This brings clarity to all involved, but might be getting too fancy.

Adapted to pytest (as of version 6.1), this would be:

```py
# Existing class
class PytestDeprecationWarning(PytestWarning, DeprecationWarning): ...

# New class
class PytestExpiredDeprecationWarning(PytestWarning, DeprecationWarning): ...

# New class
class PytestPendingDeprecationWarning(PytestWarning, PendingDeprecationWarning): ...
```

```py
class PytestRemovedInPytest7Warning(PytestDeprecationWarning): ...

class PytestRemovedInPytest8Warning(PytestPendingDeprecationWarning): ...
```

When pytest 7 is released, changes to

```py
class PytestRemovedInPytest7Warning(PytestExpiredDeprecationWarning): ...

class PytestRemovedInPytest8Warning(PytestDeprecationWarning): ...

class PytestRemovedInPytest9Warning(PytestPendingDeprecationWarning): ...
```

When pytest 7.1 is released, changes to

```py
class PytestRemovedInPytest8Warning(PytestDeprecationWarning): ...

class PytestRemovedInPytest9Warning(PytestPendingDeprecationWarning): ...
```

The `PytestDeprecationWarning` should be used when adding deprecations right before a major release (when we had this case in pytest 6.0, we disabled them until after the release instead).
based on experiences in pip and a few internal tools, the self version dependency seems orders of magnitude better than any manually managed way to deal with it
